Instructions En: Use in patients presenting to the emergency department with acute dyspnea secondary to new-onset or chronic heart failure (HF), after initial intervention. Do not use prior to ED intervention. Do not use in patients who are hemodynamically unstable (see When to Use for full exclusion criteria).

Medium Description En: Assesses mental impairment in elderly patients.
Short Description En: Mental status, similar performance as AMT-10 but shorter.

Full Title En: Murray Score for Acute Lung Injury
Medium Description En: Stratifies severity of acute lung injury, and is also used for ECMO patient selection.
Instructions En: Use in patients with severe hypoxemic respiratory failure from acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). May be used with other clinical factors to help select patients for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
Before Use: Tips for COVID-19: Use to determine ECMO. Standard score for determining when ECMO indicated. Used in CESAR trial, a pivotal RCT in ECMO.

Full Title En: Clinical Index of Stable Febrile Neutropenia (CISNE)
Medium Description En: Identifies febrile neutropenia patients at low risk of serious complications.
Instructions En: Use in adult outpatients at least 18 years old with solid tumor, fever at least 38°C (100.4°F) over 1 hr, and neutropenia (500 cells/mm³or fewer, or 1,000 cells/mm³ with expected decrease to 500). Do not use in patients with acute organ failure, severe infection, hypotension, or other reason for admission.

Medium Description En: Predicts likelihood of lower extremity cellulitis over other diagnoses.
Instructions En: Use in adult patients presenting to the ED with a red leg and clinical concern for cellulitis. Do not use if: visible abscess/fluctuance, penetrating trauma, burn, diabetic ulcer, hardware/device, post-operative patient, or recent (within 48 hrs) IV antibiotic use.

Medium Description En: Predicts successful extubation, to be used only as a single component of the clinical picture.
Instructions En: Use in intubated patients breathing spontaneously who meet other clinical criteria for weaning from mechanical ventilation. The RSBI should not be the sole determinant of extubation.
Before Use: Tips for COVID-19: Use to determine floor vs. ICU. Predicts successful extubation.

Medium Description En: Identifies patients at high risk for type 2 diabetes.
Predicts risk of developing type 2 diabetes.

Full Title En: Bova Score for Pulmonary Embolism Complications
Medium Description En: Predicts 30-day risk of PE-related complications in hemodynamically stable patients.
Instructions En: Use ONLY in hemodynamically stable patients (sBP ≥90) with confirmed acute PE (pulmonary embolism).

Full Title En: HERDOO2 Rule for Discontinuing Anticoagulation in Unprovoked VTE
Medium Description En: Identifies low-risk women who can safely discontinue VTE treatment.
Instructions En: Use in women ≥18 years old with unprovoked VTE. Do not use in patients with any of the following at the time of VTE diagnosis: leg fracture, lower-extremity plaster cast, immobilization >3 days, general anesthesia <3 months before, or cancer diagnosis within 5 years.

Full Title En: mMRC (Modified Medical Research Council) Dyspnea Scale
Medium Description En: Stratifies severity of dyspnea in respiratory diseases, particularly COPD.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome.
Instructions En:
Use in patients with symptoms suggestive of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) such as chronic and recurrent abdominal pain and/or altered bowel habits for at least 6 months. 

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though IBS may be present:

  • Signs or symptoms of gastrointestinal bleeding.

  • Unexplained iron deficiency anemia.

  • Unintentional weight loss.

  • Palpable abdominal mass or lymphadenopathy on exam.

  • Family history of colon cancer and have not had age-appropriate colon cancer screening.

  • Onset of symptoms age ≥50 years and have not had age-appropriate colon cancer screening.

  • Sudden or acute onset of new change in bowel habit.

Medium Description En: Quantifies level of daytime sleepiness.
Predicts large vessel occlusion (LVO) and severe stroke in patients with stroke symptoms.
Instructions En: Use in a hospital setting in patients with signs and symptoms of acute ischemic stroke.

Full Title En: Nutrition Risk in the Critically Ill (NUTRIC) Score
Medium Description En: Identifies critically ill patients who can benefit from nutrition therapy, recommended by ACG guidelines.
Predicts risk of malnutrition in hospitalized patients, recommended by ACG guidelines.
Predicts mortality in patients with pleural infection.
Instructions En: Use in patients with confirmed pleural infection.

Full Title En: National Cancer Institute Common Toxicity Criteria (NCI-CTC) for Mucositis
Medium Description En: Grades severity of radiation-induced mucositis.
Instructions En: Use in patients with radiation-induced mucositis.

Full Title En: LENT Prognostic Score for Malignant Pleural Effusion
Medium Description En: Predicts survival in patients with malignant pleural effusion.

Full Title En: Brief Resolved Unexplained Events (BRUE) Criteria for Infants
Medium Description En: Classifies unexplained events and replaces the Apparent Life Threatening Events (ALTE) classification.
Instructions En: Use in infants <1 year old who are asymptomatic and in their normal state of health at the time of evaluation. Do not use in symptomatic patients (e.g. fever, respiratory distress) or those with obvious cause for prior symptoms.
Before Use: BRUE has been updated. BRUE 2.0 has been recommended as a replacement for the older tool. Click here to view.

Medium Description En: Predicts mortality or acute kidney injury (AKI) in rhabdomyolysis patients.
Instructions En: Use in patients ≥18 years old with rhabdomyolysis (CPK >5,000 U/L within 72 hours of admission). Do not use in patients with pre-existing end-stage renal disease or with elevated CPK due to MI.

Full Title En: DECAF Score for Acute Exacerbation of COPD
Medium Description En: Predicts in-hospital mortality in acute COPD exacerbation.
Instructions En: Use in patients ≥35 years old, hospitalized with a primary diagnosis of acute exacerbation of COPD. Do not use in patients with comorbidity expected to limit survival <12 months.

Full Title En: BAP-65 Score for Acute Exacerbation of COPD
Medium Description En: Predicts mortality in acute COPD exacerbation.
Instructions En: Use in patients >40 years of age presenting to the emergency department with acute COPD exacerbation. Use the worst variables on the day of admission.

Medium Description En: Rules out coronary artery disease in primary care patients with chest pain.
Instructions En: Do not use in an emergency setting.

Medium Description En: Doses naloxone for acute opioid overdose.
Instructions En: Use in patients with respiratory or central nervous system depression from opioid analgesic overdose.
Before Use: This dosing tool is intended to assist with calculation, not to provide comprehensive or definitive drug information. Always double-check dosing of any drug and consult a pharmacist when necessary.

Medium Description En: Predicts need for urgent delivery based on sonographic and nonstress testing.

Full Title En: Intraoperative Fluid Dosing in Adult Patients
Medium Description En: Doses IV fluids intraoperatively.
Instructions En: Use in patients undergoing surgery who weigh ≥20 kg and do not have conditions that could otherwise result in fluid overload such as heart failure, COPD, or kidney failure on dialysis. This calculator provides a base hourly fluid requirement, fluid deficit, and hour-by-hour fluid requirement based on surgical needs.
Before Use: This dosing tool is intended to assist with calculation, not to provide comprehensive or definitive drug information. Always double-check dosing of any drug and consult a pharmacist when necessary.

Medium Description En: Doses insulin for calcium-channel blocker or beta blocker overdose.
Instructions En: Use in patients with cardiac drug-induced myocardial depression (cardiogenic shock).
Before Use: This dosing tool is intended to assist with calculation, not to provide comprehensive or definitive drug information. Always double-check dosing of any drug and consult a pharmacist when necessary.

Medium Description En: Stratifies primary blast lung injuries into three categories to guide ventilator treatment.
Instructions En: Use in patients who have sustained blast injury and have respiratory symptoms (e.g. cough, cyanosis, dyspnea, hemoptysis).

Medium Description En: Classifies types of wound closure.
Instructions En: Use in patients with open wounds, with a focus on wounds resulting from trauma.

Full Title En: Bastion Classification of Lower Limb Blast Injuries
Medium Description En: Stratifies blast injuries of lower limbs to guide treatment.
Instructions En: Identify mechanism by the most proximal extent of the injury.

Medium Description En: Predicts 12-month risk of hypoglycemic episodes in T2DM patients.
Doses plasma for transfusion in patients with active bleeding.
Instructions En: Absolute contraindications to transfusion of fresh frozen plasma (FFP): documented intolerance to plasma or components, congenital IgA deficiency with anti-IgA antibodies, etc. Relative contraindications: heart failure, pulmonary edema, etc. Plasma should be ABO-compatible with recipient.
Before Use: This dosing tool is intended to assist with calculation, not to provide comprehensive or definitive transfusion information. Always double-check dosing of any drug and consult a pharmacist or clinical pathologist as necessary.

Full Title En: Corrected Count Increment (CCI) for Platelet Transfusion
Medium Description En: Assesses adequacy of response to platelet transfusion.
Stratifies severity of illness and predicts mortality in pediatric patients after trauma.
Instructions En: Use on admission in pediatric patients <18 years old who have sustained blunt or penetrating trauma or penetrating blast injury. Use lab values obtained on admission.

Medium Description En: Doses DigiFab in patients with confirmed digoxin poisoning or overdose.
Instructions En:
Therapeutic range for serum digoxin level is 0.8–2.0 ng/mL (1.0–2.6 nmol/L). If acute poisoning and serum digoxin confirmed >10 ng/mL, give empiric dose (10-20 vials). See Evidence for details.

Additional considerations for treatment of digoxin toxicity include:

  • Atropine 0.5 mg IV for acute toxicity if bradydysrhythmias or high degree AV block.
  • Cautious correction of electrolyte abnormalities, specifically hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia (may result in dysrhythmias at lower serum digoxin levels).
Before Use: This dosing tool is intended to assist with calculation, not to provide comprehensive or definitive drug information. Always double-check dosing of any drug and consult a pharmacist when necessary.

Full Title En: Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST)
Medium Description En: Predicts presence of pericardial or intra-abdominal injury after penetrating or blunt trauma.
Instructions En: FAST results alone should not dictate the decision to operate, and negative FAST does not exclude injury. This calculator is meant to help with interpretation of FAST findings, which are at least partially dependent on the user's sonographic technique.

Full Title En: Gupta Perioperative Risk for Myocardial Infarction or Cardiac Arrest (MICA)
Medium Description En: Predicts risk of MI or cardiac arrest after surgery.
Instructions En: Use within 30 days of surgery (pre- or postoperatively). May be used in cardiac or noncardiac procedures.

Medium Description En: Estimates mortality in ICU patients, comparable to APACHE II.
Instructions En: Use the worst values in the past 24 hours.

Medium Description En: Distinguishes ventricular tachycardia from supraventricular tachycardia.
Doses antivenom (CroFab only, not Anavip) for pit viper snakebites.
Instructions En: Use only in cases of symptomatic crotalid snake envenomation (pit vipers including rattlesnakes, cottonmouths, and copperheads) in the US, for CroFab administration. Do not use in cases of coral snake envenomation or snakes not indigenous to the US. Do not use for Anavip administration, as it will result in incorrect dosing. Report all cases of suspected/confirmed envenomation to poison control (1-800-222-1222).
Before Use: This dosing tool is intended to assist with calculation, not to provide comprehensive or definitive drug information. Always double-check dosing of any drug and consult a pharmacist when necessary.

Medium Description En: Determines whether febrile infants are low risk for serious bacterial infection.
Instructions En: Use in febrile infants ≤60 days of age (rectal temp ≥38°C or 100.4°F).

Medium Description En: Predicts risk for community-acquired pneumonia due to drug-resistant pathogens.
Short Description En: Drug-resistant CAP risk, more accurate than Shorr Score.

Medium Description En: Doses fomepizole for methanol and ethylene glycol reversal.
Diagnoses hypertension in pediatric patients; official guideline of the American Academy of Pediatrics.
Instructions En: Use in children aged 1-17 years. Not for use in patients with low blood pressure. Recommendations are based on AAP's 2017 Clinical Practice Guideline (Table 3). Note that cutoffs reported in the calculator may vary slightly from the published tables, as the calculator accommodates for ages between whole numbers (e.g. 5.5 years), and the tables use simplified values to account for ages between whole numbers. For children ≥13 years of age, this calculator has been adjusted to meet definitions presented in the 2017 AHA/ACC hypertension guidelines for adults.
Before Use: This tool has been developed in partnership with the American Academy of Pediatrics. The authors, editors, and contributors are expert authorities in the field of pediatrics. No commercial involvement of any kind has been solicited or accepted in the development of the content of this tool. Advertising does not influence editorial decisions or content. The appearance of advertising on MDCalc sites is neither a guarantee nor an endorsement by the AAP of the product, service, or company, or the claims made for the product in such advertising.

Full Title En: Mantle Cell Lymphoma International Prognostic Index (MIPI)
Medium Description En: Predicts survival in patients with mantle cell lymphoma.

Full Title En: International Prognostic Index for Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL-IPI)
Medium Description En: Stratifies patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia into four risk categories.

Full Title En: RADS (Radiologists Score) for Smoke Inhalation Injury
Medium Description En: Stratifies severity of inhalation injury on chest CT.
Instructions En: Requires chest CT to calculate. This tool computes RADS for a single slice; to obtain full score (average RADS per slice), add RADS for all slices and divide by number of slices.

Full Title En: Abbreviated Injury Score (AIS) for Inhalation Injury
Medium Description En: Classifies inhalation injury severity based on bronchoscopic findings.
Instructions En: Use in adult patients with suspected inhalation injury undergoing flexible bronchoscopy.

Full Title En: Solitary Pulmonary Nodule (SPN) Malignancy Risk Score (Mayo Clinic Model)
Medium Description En: Predicts malignancy risk in solitary lung nodules on chest x-ray.
Instructions En: Do not use in patients with prior lung cancer diagnosis or with history of extrathoracic cancer diagnosed within 5 years of nodule presentation.

Medium Description En: Stratifies severity of depressive episodes in adults.
Instructions En: Use in adults only (≥18 years). Rate based on clinical interview with the patient. Use clinical judgment to determine whether the rating lies on the defined scale steps (0, 2, 4, 6 points) or between them (1, 3, 5 points, denoted as "(Worsening symptoms)").

Medium Description En: Stratifies severity of organ failure in an ICU setting.
Stratifies severity of esophagitis based on endoscopic findings, recommended by ACG guidelines.
Differentiates cholestatic from hepatocellular liver injury, recommended by ACG guidelines.
Instructions En: Use the first lab values (ALT and ALP) indicating acute liver injury to calculate the R factor.

Medium Description En: Calculates total blood volume, red blood cell volume, and plasma volume.
Estimates the volume of donor RBCs needed for RBC exchange in patients with sickle cell disease.
Instructions En: Note: device manufacturers may provide separate calculations for automated exchange.

Medium Description En: Helps rule out pulmonary embolism; also validated in pregnant patients with clinically suspected PE.
Instructions En:
Use in hemodynamically stable patients ≥18 years old.

Take note of the following exclusion criteria:

  • Treatment with therapeutic doses of anticoagulants initiated 24 hours or more before eligibility assessment.
  • Life expectancy less than 3 months.
  • Geographic inaccessibility precluding follow-up.
  • Pregnancy (be sure to use pregnancy-adapted YEARS algorithm in the calc).
  • Allergy to intravenous contrast agent.

Medium Description En: Calculates impact factor, based on Journal Citation Reports formula.
Diagnoses fatty liver using labs and exam findings.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Functional Dyspepsia
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of functional dyspepsia.
Instructions En:
Use in patients with symptoms suggestive of functional dyspepsia such as chronic and recurrent epigastric pain, discomfort, fullness, burning and early satiety for at least 6 months.

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though functional dyspepsia may be present:

  • Signs or symptoms of GI bleeding.
  • Unexplained iron deficiency anemia.
  • Unintentional weight loss.
  • Palpable abdominal mass or lymphadenopathy on exam.
  • Family history of gastric cancer and no recent upper endoscopy.
  • Dysphagia.
  • Persistent vomiting.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Functional Constipation
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of functional constipation.
Instructions En:
Use in patients with symptoms suggestive of constipation for at least the last 3 months.

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though functional constipation may be present:

  • Signs or symptoms of gastrointestinal bleeding.
  • Unexplained iron deficiency anemia.
  • Unintentional weight loss.
  • Palpable abdominal mass or lymphadenopathy on exam.
  • Family history of colon cancer and have not had age-appropriate colon cancer screening.
  • Onset of symptoms age ≥50 years and have not had age-appropriate colon cancer screening.
  • Sudden or acute onset of new change in bowel habit.

Medium Description En: Estimates volume of donor RBCs needed for intrauterine transfusion (IUT).
Before Use: This dosing tool is intended to assist with calculation, not to provide comprehensive or definitive drug information. Always double-check dosing of any drug and consult your institution's blood bank or a pharmacist as necessary.

Medium Description En: Estimates volume of cryoprecipitate recommended for fibrinogen replacement.
Before Use: This dosing tool is intended to assist with calculation, not to provide comprehensive or definitive drug information. Always double-check dosing of any drug and consult a pharmacist when necessary.

Medium Description En: Estimates the volume of whole blood to remove and volume of crystalloid to infuse in neonatal polycythemia.
Before Use: This dosing tool is intended to assist with calculation, not to provide comprehensive or definitive drug information. Always double-check dosing of any drug and consult your institution's blood bank or a pharmacist as necessary.

Full Title En: Revised Schwartz Equation for Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) (2009)
Medium Description En: Estimates GFR in pediatric patients.
Estimates CD34+ yield using pre-apheresis peripheral blood absolute CD34 blood count.
Before Use: This dosing tool is intended to assist with calculation, not to provide comprehensive or definitive drug information. Always double-check dosing of any drug and consult a pharmacist when necessary. It is important that clinical decisions are made only from laboratory results on validated instruments.

Full Title En: Maternal-Fetal Hemorrhage Rh(D) Immune Globulin Dosage
Medium Description En: Calculates amount of RhIG to be administered to the mother, at the time of delivery, to prevent hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN).
Before Use: This dosing tool is intended to assist with calculation, not to provide comprehensive or definitive drug information. Always double-check dosing of any drug and consult a clinical pathologist or pharmacist when necessary.

Full Title En: RBC Units to Screen for Compatibility
Medium Description En: Estimates number of donor RBC units to screen to obtain a desired number of antigen-negative units.
Estimates volume of whole blood to process by apheresis to yield an appropriate DLI dosage.
Estimates amount of a substance (e.g. antibody) remaining in the intravascular space after a given number of plasma volume exchanges.
Short Description En: Removal of a substance by plasma exchange.

Full Title En: IMPACT Score for Outcomes in Head Injury
Medium Description En: Predicts 6-month mortality and unfavorable outcomes after moderate to severe traumatic brain injury (TBI).
Instructions En: Use for patients ≥14 years old with GCS ≤12 (moderate and severe TBI). Use data from the first 24 hours of admission.

Full Title En: EPIPHANY Index for Pulmonary Embolism (PE) in Cancer
Medium Description En: Predicts risk of serious complications in cancer patients with pulmonary embolism.
Instructions En: Use in adults (>18 years) with cancer and PE (symptomatic or incidental) confirmed on imaging (i.e., CT, CT angiography, V/Q scan). Do not use if PE diagnosed >1 month before cancer diagnosis, or if PE diagnosed >1 month since completing chemotherapy.

Medium Description En: Predicts which patients will benefit from prolonged DAPT after coronary stent placement.
Short Description En: Prolonged (>1 year) dual antiplatelet therapy after PCI.

Medium Description En: Classifies stool (correlates with intestinal transit time).

Full Title En: AKIN Classification for Acute Kidney Injury (AKI)
Medium Description En: Classifies severity of acute kidney injury, similar to RIFLE Criteria.
Instructions En: Patients on renal replacement therapy (RRT) are considered to be stage 3 regardless of whether they meet formal criteria.

Full Title En: RIFLE Criteria for Acute Kidney Injury (AKI)
Medium Description En: Classifies severity of acute kidney injury, similar to AKIN Classification.
Instructions En: Note: the original paper refers to "acute renal failure", but the generally-accepted term currently is "acute kidney injury", which is reflected in this calculator.

Full Title En: ACTION ICU Score for Intensive Care in NSTEMI
Medium Description En: Predicts risk of NSTEMI complications requiring ICU care.
Instructions En: Use in emergency patients with NSTEMI.
Before Use: This calculator is not externally validated, and as such, should be used with caution.

Full Title En: ARISCAT Score for Postoperative Pulmonary Complications
Medium Description En: Predicts risk of pulmonary complications after surgery, including respiratory failure.

Full Title En: Leiden Clinical Prediction Rule for Undifferentiated Arthritis
Medium Description En: Diagnoses rheumatoid arthritis in patients with recent-onset undifferentiated arthritis.
Classifies health of patients prior to surgery.
Identifies patients that may benefit from therapy to lower intraocular pressure (IOP).

Full Title En: Wexler and Lok Formula for PCO<sub>2</sub>
Medium Description En: Calculates required minute ventilation for a given PCO2.
Short Title En: Wexler and Lok Formula for PCO<sub>2</sub>

Full Title En: Recognition of Stroke in the Emergency Room (ROSIER) Scale
Medium Description En: Distinguishes between acute stroke and stroke mimics.
Predicts risk of in-hospital cardiac arrest.

Full Title En: CholeS Score for Duration of Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy
Medium Description En: Predicts operative time of laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
Estimates risk of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in patients with chronic hepatitis B.

Full Title En: GO-FAR (Good Outcome Following Attempted Resuscitation) Score
Medium Description En: Predicts survival to discharge with good outcome after in-hospital cardiac arrest.
Instructions En: Use pre-arrest information to calculate.
Short Description En: Survival and good outcome after cardiac arrest.

Full Title En: SLICC Criteria for Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) 2012
Medium Description En: Provides criteria for diagnosis of SLE.
Instructions En: Criteria are cumulative; i.e., any history counts and findings need not be present concurrently.

Medium Description En: Predicts compliance with opioid treatment for chronic noncancer pain.
Assigns phenotype in patients with ischemic stroke of uncertain causes.
Grades severity of GVHD post stem cell transplant.
Identifies patients at risk for pressure ulcers.
Provides criteria for psoriatic arthritis diagnosis.

Full Title En: Duval/CIBMTR Score for Acute Myelogenous Leukemia (AML) Survival
Medium Description En: Predicts overall survival in AML patients with relapsed/refractory disease undergoing myeloablative transplant.
Instructions En: Use in patients with relapsed or refractory active AML for whom hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT) is being considered. Do not use in patients with chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) in blast crisis.

Medium Description En: Assesses severity of CRS in patients on immunotherapy.
Instructions En: Use in patients receiving immunotherapy for cancer.

Medium Description En: Stratifies severity of depression, similar to PHQ-9.
Instructions En: The original HAM-D has 21 items, but scoring is based only on the first 17.

Full Title En: Rai Staging System for Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL)

Instructions En: Use in patients with lymphocytosis (absolute lymphocytes ≥15,000/mm3 in blood and ≥40% lymphocytes in marrow). Lymph nodes, spleen, and liver are considered enlarged if palpable on exam.

Instructions En: Use in blunt trauma patients 4-16 years of age.

Full Title En: PEDIS Score for Diabetic Foot Ulcers
Medium Description En: Predicts 6-month risk of amputation and mortality in diabetic foot ulcers.
Instructions En: Use in an inpatient setting in patients with diabetic foot ulcer of any duration. Do not use in patients with secondary diabetes or those with foot ulcers caused by autoimmune disease or malignancy.

Medium Description En: Assess binocular and monocular visual acuity.
Instructions En:
• Ensure proper room lighting and set phone brightness to 100%.
  • Hold the screen 4 feet (1.2 m) from the patient (approximately the end of a standard hospital bed if patient is sitting upright).
  • Test each eye independently. The patient should completely cover the opposite eye.
  • See Pearls/Pitfalls for further instructions.
Before Use: This calculator is intended as a convenient screener for visual acuity to be used on a mobile device and should not be used as a replacement for in-office testing. Evidence for smartphone apps for Snellen visual acuity is limited, and currently no app has been found to be accurate to within at least one line of formal visual acuity testing (and further validation is required). Variation in screen resolution and text size may impact accuracy.

Medium Description En: Assess for red-green color blindness.
Instructions En:
• Ensure proper room lighting and phone brightness.

  • Wear any glasses necessary for near vision.

  • Hold screen at a comfortable reading distance (~30 inches or 75 cm).

  • Test each eye independently.

Full Title En: Fleischner Society Guidelines for Incidental Pulmonary Nodules
Medium Description En: Provides guidelines for management of solid and subsolid pulmonary nodules.
Instructions En: Use in patients ≥35 years old with incidental pulmonary nodules on CT imaging. Do not use for lung cancer screening or in patients with known primary cancer or immunosuppression. Use most suspicious nodule as guide to management.

Medium Description En: Predicts probability of hydronephrosis on renal ultrasonography (RUS) requiring urologic intervention in adult patients with acute kidney injury.

Full Title En: Wexner Score for Obstructed Defecation Syndrome (ODS)

Medium Description En: Estimates survival in patients with primary myelofibrosis.

Full Title En: NAFLD (Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease) Activity Score

Instructions En: Use in patients who have had liver biopsy for NAFLD. The score should not be used as a surrogate for NASH diagnosis (see Brunt and Kleiner 2011 for details).

Medium Description En: Stratifies severity of Crohn's disease.

Full Title En: REVEAL Registry Risk Score 2.0 for Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH)

New and/or revised variables include hospitalizations in the last 6 months and eGFR/renal insufficiency. Other previously existing variables were also studied and modified as supported in literature. Please see references listed in Evidence for further details.

Instructions En:

Note: We recommend using PECARN over other pediatric head trauma rules, as it is the most widely validated (see Next Steps for details).
Short Title En: Peds NEXUS II Head CT Decision Instrument

Medium Description En: Differentiates normal variant ST elevation (benign early repolarization) from anterior STEMI, more sensitive than 3-variable version.
Instructions En:
Note: this calculator replaces the older 3-variable version and is recommended by MDCalc and Dr. Stephen Smith. Before using this calculator, make sure the EKG shows ≥1 mm ST elevation (STE) in ≥1 of the precordial leads V2-V4. If it shows any one of the following, then it is NOT normal variant, and is very likely to be LAD occlusion; such cases were excluded from the study as "obvious" MI:

  • >5 mm STE.
  • Non-concave STE.
  • Inferior reciprocal changes.
  • Anterior ST depression.
  • Terminal QRS distortion in V2 or V3:
  • Q waves in any of V2 to V4.
  • Any T wave inversion from V2 to V6.
Short Description En: Normal variant ST elevation vs true anterior STEMI.

Medium Description En: Calculates maximum daily dose of hydroxychloroquine to reduce of retinopathy.
Instructions En: This calculator is for double-checking hydroxychloroquine dosing, and should NOT be used as the primary means for ordering.
Before Use:
• Note: Neither hydroxychloroquine NOR chloroquine are FDA approved to treat COVID-19. No drugs are FDA approved to treat COVID-19 (Coronavirus Disease 2019).
  • Short term Plaquenil has none/minimal risk for retinopathy. See the American Journal of Ophthalmology for more information.

Full Title En: Paradise Criteria for Tonsillectomy in Children

Instructions En: Use only in patients aged 1-18 years in whom tonsillectomy is being considered. Do not use in children with diabetes mellitus, cardiopulmonary disease, craniofacial disorders, congenital anomalies of the head/neck, sickle cell disease or other coagulopathies, or immunodeficiency disorders.

Full Title En: WPSS (WHO classification-based Prognostic Scoring System) for Myelodysplastic Syndrome
Medium Description En: Evaluates prognosis of patients with myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS).
Determines the degree of illness of a patient and prompts critical care intervention (recommended by NHS over original NEWS).
Instructions En: Recommended by the NHS (UK) over the original NEWS.
Before Use: Tips for COVID-19: Use for Crisis Standards of Care. Used for subgroup analyses (not for Crises Standards of Care) in Cao et al (2020) NEJM’s Lopinavir-Ritonavir study in COVID-19.
Short Description En: Severity screening of declining conditions, recommended over original NEWS.

Full Title En: RegiSCAR Score for Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Medium Description En: Diagnoses drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS).

Medium Description En: Quantifies burden of disease in elderly patients (comorbidity scale).

Before Use: Tips for COVID-19: Screens for cytokine storm (including in COVID-19), when immunosuppression may be helpful (immunosuppression not yet shown to be beneficial).

Medium Description En: Predicts risk of delirium during hospitalization.

Instructions En: Do not use to calculate initial dose for a benzo-naïve patient.
Before Use: This calculator should be used as a reference for oral benzodiazepine conversions. Equipotent benzodiazepine doses are reported as ranges due to paucity of literature supporting exact conversions, thus reported ranges are based on expert opinion and clinical experience published in psychiatric literature.

Medium Description En: Diagnoses rheumatoid arthritis (RA) in patients with undifferentiated inflammatory synovitis.
Instructions En: Use in patients who have at least one swollen joint and no better explanation for synovitis.

Medium Description En: MDCalc and First Republic have teamed up to offer the best available interest rates for student loan repayment for medical professionals.
Instructions En: Note: student loan interest deduction not valid at the attending physician level.

Before Use:
This calculator includes inputs based on race, which may or may not provide better estimates, so we have decided to make race optional. See here for more on our approach to addressing race and bias on MDCalc.

Instructions En:
• Use in otherwise healthy neonates ≥35 weeks gestational age (GA) at the time of discharge. Do not use in neonates with positive direct Coombs test, or in those requiring phototherapy before 60 hours of age. Do not use to determine need for exchange transfusion.

  • The recommendations listed here for starting phototherapy are based on AAP guidelines. Always use clinical judgment, in addition to considering evidence-based clinical guidelines, in making treatment decisions.

Full Title En: Withdrawal Assessment Tool (WAT-1) for Pediatric Withdrawal
Medium Description En: Estimates severity of opioid and benzodiazepine withdrawal in children.

Full Title En: Columbia Suicide Severity Rating Scale (C-SSRS Screener)

Instructions En: Note there are several versions of the C-SSRS; this is the screener version, which is a truncated version of the full scale intended for emergency settings.
Short Title En: Columbia Suicide Severity Rating Scale Screener

Medium Description En: Calculates total daily morphine milligram equivalents.
Instructions En:
Note: This is for converting oral opioids only, and should not be used for IV to oral conversions. 

For combination drugs (e.g. Percocet = acetaminophen + oxyCODONE), enter only the dose of the opioid component (e.g. if 5 mg/325 mg, enter "5"). Do not use in pediatric patients, due to unpredictable rates of absorption and risk of overdose.

As a partial opioid agonist, buprenorphine is not expected to be associated with overdose risk in the same dose-dependent manner as doses for full agonist opioids and is therefore omitted from the calculator.
Before Use:
There is no completely safe opioid dose, and this calculator does not substitute for clinical judgment. Use caution when prescribing opioids at any dosage, and prescribe the lowest effective dose.

Conversions are based on the CDC Clinical Practice Guideline for Prescribing Opioids for Pain — United States, 2022.

Medium Description En: Screens for suicidality in emergency patients.

Medium Description En: Screens for pediatric delirium.
Instructions En: Do not use in patients with Richmond Agitation-Sedation Scale (RASS) ≤-4 (deep sedation: no response to voice, but movement or eye opening to physical stimulation, or unarousable: no response to voice or physical stimulation). Includes developmental anchor points for children at 8 weeks and 1 year to improve screening accuracy in very young patients.

This calculator includes inputs based on race, which may or may not provide better estimates, so we have decided to make race optional. See here for more on our approach to addressing race and bias on MDCalc.

Instructions En: Use in patients with prostate cancer. Do not use for screening or diagnosis.

Medium Description En: Predicts risk of pneumonia after surgery.

Do not use in patients who have already undergone plasma exchange (i.e., intermediate and high risk groups, in whom therapeutic plasma exchange must be initiated immediately).

Medium Description En: Quantifies malnutrition, validated in many populations.
Instructions En: Note: although weight and nutritional status are not always correlated (e.g. obese patients may have malnutrition), for the purposes of this calculator, patients with increased weight from baseline (present weight > usual weight) are unlikely to have malnutrition. Always use clinical judgment.

Full Title En: ISTH Criteria for Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)

Before Use: Tips for COVID-19: This is one measure of COVID-19 associated coagulopathy, which was associated with poor prognosis (Tang 2020).

Medium Description En: Doses local anesthetics to help avoid toxic doses.
Instructions En: Note: Previous versions of Goldfrank’s reported an increased maximum allowable dosage due to the vasoconstrictive effects of epinephrine when added to local anesthetics. The most recent version no longer includes this adjustment. While there likely is a higher safe dose when epinephrine is added, we no longer include that estimate on this calculator, and as always, dosages should be double-checked and reviewed using your local pharmacy and policies.
Before Use: This calculator provides guidance for maximum dosing of local anesthetic and should not be used as the primary means of dosing. Always double check and err on the side of caution.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Functional Diarrhea
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of functional diarrhea.
Instructions En:
Use in patients with symptoms of chronic diarrhea for at least the last 6 months where there is not a clear systemic cause for diarrhea (e.g. secondary diarrhea).

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though functional diarrhea may be present:

  • Signs or symptoms of gastrointestinal bleeding.

  • Unexplained iron deficiency anemia.

  • Unintentional weight loss or evidence of malnutrition.

  • Palpable abdominal mass or lymphadenopathy on exam.

  • Family history of colon cancer and have not had age-appropriate colon cancer screening. Family history of inflammatory bowel disease or celiac disease.

  • Onset of symptoms age ≥50 years and have not had age-appropriate colon cancer screening.

  • Sudden or acute onset of new change in bowel habit.

  • Diarrhea awakening the patient at night.

  • Recent antibiotic use.

  • High volume diarrhea.

  • Fever.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Functional Abdominal Bloating/Distension
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of functional abdominal bloating or distension.
Instructions En:
Use in patients with symptoms of abdominal bloating and/or distension for at least the last 6 months where there is not a clear systemic cause for their symptoms. 

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though functional abdominal bloating/distension may be present:

  • Signs or symptoms of gastrointestinal bleeding.

  • Unexplained iron deficiency anemia.

  • Unintentional weight loss.

  • Palpable abdominal mass or lymphadenopathy on exam.

  • Family history of colon cancer and have not had age-appropriate colon cancer screening.

  • Onset of symptoms age ≥50 years and have not had age-appropriate colon cancer screening.

  • Sudden or acute onset of new change in bowel habit.

  • Symptoms suggestive of bowel obstruction.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Unspecified Functional Bowel Disorder
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of unspecified functional bowel disorder.
Instructions En:
Use in patients who present with bowel symptoms for at least 6 months for which there is no systemic cause or other functional bowel disorder.

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though functional constipation may be present:

  • Signs or symptoms of gastrointestinal bleeding.

  • Unexplained iron deficiency anemia.

  • Unintentional weight loss.

  • Palpable abdominal mass or lymphadenopathy on exam.

  • Family history of colon cancer and have not had age-appropriate colon cancer screening.

  • Onset of symptoms age ≥50 years and have not had age-appropriate colon cancer screening.

  • Sudden or acute onset of new change in bowel habit.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Opioid-Induced Constipation
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of opioid-induced constipation.
Instructions En:
Use in patients with symptoms suggestive of constipation in the setting of opioid use.

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though opioid induced constipation may be present:

  • Signs or symptoms of gastrointestinal bleeding.

  • Unexplained iron deficiency anemia.

  • Unintentional weight loss.

  • Palpable abdominal mass or lymphadenopathy on exam.

  • Family history of colon cancer and have not had age-appropriate colon cancer screening.

  • Onset of symptoms age ≥50 years and have not had age-appropriate colon cancer screening.

  • Sudden or acute onset of new change in bowel habit that occurred prior to initiation or dose change of an opioid.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Functional Chest Pain
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of functional chest pain.
Instructions En:
Use in patients with symptoms suggestive of functional chest pain such as recurrent, unexplained chest pain or discomfort for at least 6 months.

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though functional chest pain may be present:

  • Symptoms suggestive of cardiac ischemia.

  • Dysphagia.

  • Unexplained iron deficiency anemia.

  • Unintentional weight loss.

  • Palpable cervical lymphadenopathy on exam.

  • Persistent vomiting.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnosis Criteria for Functional Heartburn
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of functional heartburn.
Instructions En:
Use in patients with symptoms suggestive of functional heartburn, such as recurrent burning retrosternal discomfort or pain for at least 6 months, which is not responsive to antisecretory therapy. 

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though functional heartburn may be present:

  • Symptoms suggestive of cardiac ischemia.

  • Dysphagia.

  • Unexplained iron deficiency anemia.

  • Unintentional weight loss.

  • Palpable cervical lymphadenopathy on exam.

  • Persistent vomiting.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Reflux Hypersensitivity
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of reflux hypersensitivity.
Instructions En:
Use in patients with symptoms suggestive of reflux hypersensitivity, such as unexplained recurrent retrosternal symptoms (including heartburn and chest pain), for at least 6 months.

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though functional heartburn may be present:

  • Symptoms suggestive of cardiac ischemia.

  • Dysphagia.

  • Unexplained iron deficiency anemia.

  • Unintentional weight loss.

  • Palpable cervical lymphadenopathy on exam.

  • Persistent vomiting.

Medium Description En: Predicts ICU mortality in patients with community-acquired pneumonia.

Full Title En: MuLBSTA Score for Viral Pneumonia Mortality
Medium Description En: Predicts 90-day mortality in patients with viral pneumonia.
Before Use:
Launched during COVID-19 crisis. Not externally validated. Use with caution.

Tips for COVID-19: Use after diagnosis to determine dispo. Specific for Viral PNA and similar inputs as known COVID-19 mortality risk factors, but not externally validated.

Medium Description En: Predicts risk of adverse outcomes in CAP patients in the ED.
Before Use:
Launched during COVID-19 crisis.

Tips for COVID-19: Use to determine floor vs. ICU. Likely similar performance to SMART-COP.

Medium Description En: Identifies patients at high risk for developing acute lung injury (ALI).

Full Title En: PREdiction of Survival on ECMO Therapy (PRESET) Score
Medium Description En: Predicts survival after ECMO for acute respiratory distress syndrome.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Functional Dysphagia
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of functional dysphagia.
Instructions En:
Use in patients with symptoms suggestive of functional dysphagia, such as a recurrent sense of solid and/or liquid foods passing abnormally through the esophagus, for at least 6 months.

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though functional dysphagia may be present:

  • Odynophagia.

  • Sore throat.

  • Heartburn or esophageal reflux/regurgitation.

  • Unexplained iron deficiency anemia.

  • Unintentional weight loss.

  • Palpable cervical lymphadenopathy on exam.

  • Persistent vomiting.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Globus
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of globus.
Instructions En:
Use in patients with symptoms suggestive of globus, such as a persistent or intermittent non-painful sensation of a lump or foreign body in the throat, for at least 6 months.

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though globus may be present:

  • Dysphagia.

  • Odynophagia.

  • Sore throat.

  • Unexplained iron deficiency anemia.

  • Unintentional weight loss.

  • Palpable cervical lymphadenopathy on exam.

  • Persistent vomiting.

Medium Description En: Quantifies clinical severity in COVID-19 patients, as of March 12, 2020.
Instructions En:
• This is an easy to use, clinical, at-the-bedside score that can be calculated initially or trended over time to summarize overall respiratory status; in Italy it is primarily being used in association with a treatment/management algorithm. 
  • If you are an Italian physician and would like to help MDCalc update this score or provide additional or clarifying information, please email us directly at mdcalc+covid19@gmail.com.
Before Use: Launched during COVID-19 crisis. Not externally validated. Use with caution; this is being used in Italy for assessment, trending, and treatment recommendations. See also treatment/management algorithm.

Medium Description En: Step-wise management approach to COVID-19 patients based on clinical severity as of June 2, 2020.
Instructions En:
• This algorithm is a step-wise approach to managing patients with confirmed/presumed COVID-19 pneumonia. 

  • If not intubated, follow management and then each 4 testing criteria should be repeated to assess for improvement or deterioration. Repetition frequency based on clinical judgment to downgrade/upgrade score.

  • Not only is the management important; the numerical score is used to easily compare and summarize patients to treating clinicians.

  • NIV concerning for aerosolization; included in score due to ventilator scarcity in Italy.
Before Use:
• Launched during COVID-19 crisis. Not externally validated. Use with caution; this is being used in Italy for assessment, trending, and treatment recommendations.

  • See our expert interview with Italian intensivist, Dr. Simone Piva, for an in-depth discussion of how the BCRSS is being used practically to simplify and communicate the respiratory status of patients.

Full Title En: Modified Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (mSOFA) Score
Medium Description En: Predicts ICU mortality using mostly clinical variables and fewer labs (similar to SOFA Score).
Before Use: Launched during COVID-19 crisis.

Medium Description En: Screens for hypoxia in dyspneic patients.
Instructions En:
Instruct patient:

  1. Take a deep breath.

  2. In your native language, count clearly from 1 to 30 out loud, as fast as possible without stopping, until you are either out of breath or reach 30.

Clinician: Time how many seconds it takes the patient to reach 30, or until they must take another breath.

Also, record the highest number they can reach before they have to take another breath.
Before Use:
• This score has been proposed as a gross attempt to suggest hypoxia via voice/telephone, and has not been validated. Launched during COVID-19 crisis.

  • It obviously does not at all substitute for pulse oximetry or an in-person evaluation of a patient, but these are very challenging times and it is difficult to assess hypoxia without exposing healthcare workers to possible COVID, expending PPE, etc.

  • The score is based on only 93 patients being admitted for pulmonary reasons (pneumonia, COPD, CHF, etc).

Medium Description En: Calculates pressure needed to overcome elastic resistance to ventilation.
Before Use: Launched during COVID-19 crisis.

Medium Description En: Calculates IV infusion rate using drip counting when IV pumps are unavailable.
Before Use: Launched during COVID-19 crisis.

Medium Description En: Provides recommendations for management of hypoxic COVID-19 patients, official guideline of the SCCM.
Before Use: Launched during COVID-19 crisis.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Rumination Syndrome
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of rumination syndrome.
Instructions En:
Use in patients with symptoms suggestive of rumination syndrome, such as persistent or recurrent regurgitation of recently ingested food into the mouth with subsequent spitting or remastication and swallowing, for at least the past 6 months.

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though rumination syndrome may be present:

  • Signs or symptoms of GI bleeding.

  • Unexplained iron deficiency anemia.

  • Heartburn.

  • Esophageal reflux/regurgitation.

  • Unintentional weight loss.

  • Palpable abdominal mass or lymphadenopathy on exam.

  • Family history of gastric cancer and no recent upper endoscopy.

  • Dysphagia.

  • Persistent vomiting.

Full Title En: Tisdale Risk Score for QT Prolongation
Medium Description En: Predicts risk of QT prolongation greater than 500 msec in hospitalized patients.
Before Use:
Launched during COVID-19 crisis.

This score was derived and internally validated for hospitalized patients, and may not predict outpatient risk of QT prolongation as accurately (but has not been studied in this population).

Full Title En: Berlin Criteria for Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome
Medium Description En: Provides diagnostic criteria for acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
Before Use: Launched during COVID-19 crisis.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Belching Disorders
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of excessive supragastric or gastric belching.
Instructions En:
Use in patients with symptoms suggestive of a belching disorder, such as bothersome belching from the esophagus or stomach more than 3 days per week for at least 6 months.

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though a belching disorder may be present: 

  • Signs or symptoms of GI bleeding.

  • Unexplained iron deficiency anemia.

  • Unintentional weight loss.

  • Palpable abdominal mass or lymphadenopathy on exam.

  • Family history of gastric cancer and no recent upper endoscopy.

  • Dysphagia.

  • Persistent vomiting.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Chronic Nausea Vomiting Syndrome (CNVS)
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of chronic nausea vomiting syndrome (CNVS).
Instructions En:
Use in patients with symptoms suggestive of chronic nausea and vomiting syndrome (CNVS), such as bothersome nausea and vomiting for at least 6 months. 

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though CNVS may be present:

  • Signs or symptoms of GI bleeding.

  • Unexplained iron deficiency anemia.

  • Unintentional weight loss.

  • Palpable abdominal mass or lymphadenopathy on exam.

  • Family history of GI cancer and no recent abdominal imaging.

  • Acute change in GI symptoms.

  • Dysphagia.
Short Title En: Rome IV for Chronic Nausea Vomiting Syndrome

Medium Description En: Predicts poor prognosis after out-of-hospital cardiac arrest and guides utility of cardiac catheterization.
Instructions En: Use in adult patients with out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) of suspected cardiac etiology. Do not use for other causes of arrest, e.g. trauma, hanging, drowning, intoxication, overdose.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Cannabinoid Hyperemesis Syndrome (CHS)
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of cannabinoid hyperemesis syndrome.
Instructions En:
Use in patients with symptoms suggestive of cannabinoid hyperemesis syndrome (CHS) such as stereotypical episodes of vomiting, resembling cyclic vomiting syndrome (CVS), for at least the past 6 months, in the setting of prolonged cannabis use.

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though CHS may be present:

  • Signs or symptoms of GI bleeding.

  • Unexplained iron deficiency anemia.

  • Unintentional weight loss.

  • Palpable abdominal mass or lymphadenopathy on exam.

  • Family history of GI cancer and no recent upper endoscopy.

  • Dysphagia.

  • Persistent vomiting.

  • Neurologic symptoms.
Short Title En: Rome IV for Cannabinoid Hyperemesis Syndrome

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Cyclic Vomiting Syndrome
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of cyclic vomiting syndrome.
Instructions En:
Use in patients with symptoms suggestive of cyclic vomiting syndrome (CVS) such as stereotypical episodes of vomiting with at least 3 discrete episodes in the prior year and 2 episodes in the past 6 months, occurring at least 1 week apart.

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though CVS may be present:

  • Signs or symptoms of GI bleeding.

  • Unexplained iron deficiency anemia.

  • Unintentional weight loss.

  • Palpable abdominal mass or lymphadenopathy on exam.

  • Family history of gastric cancer and no recent upper endoscopy.

  • Dysphagia.

  • Persistent vomiting.

  • Neurologic symptoms.
Short Title En: Rome IV for Cyclic Vomiting Syndrome

Medium Description En: Measures frailty to predict survival.
Before Use: Launched during COVID-19 crisis.

Medium Description En: Predicts likelihood of sepsis-induced coagulopathy.
Instructions En: "Total SOFA" is the summation of the SOFA Score's Respiratory, Cardiovascular, Hepatic, and Renal SOFA components.
Before Use:
Launched during COVID-19 crisis.

The SIC Score has been evaluated in the COVID-19 crisis given concerns that COVID-19 may cause thrombosis, but this has only been evaluated in one study in China for now.

Full Title En: ROX Index for Intubation after HFNC
Medium Description En: Predicts high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) failure/need for intubation.
Instructions En: In the original paper, patients started on HFNC were reassessed at 2, 6, and 12 hours; patients whose scores were in the "indeterminate" range (3.85-4.87) were reassessed two hours later. These scores were trended over time in patients.
Before Use: Launched during COVID-19 crisis.

Medium Description En: Predicts risk of critical illness in hospitalized COVID-19 patients.
Instructions En: This score was developed in China and includes hospitalized inpatients and their risk of critical illness; the authors do not state the indications for admission.
Before Use: Launched during COVID-19 crisis.

Medium Description En: Predicts 24-hr risk of critical respiratory illness in patients admitted from ED with COVID-19.
Before Use: Launched during COVID-19 crisis.

Medium Description En: Calculates neutrophil-lymphocyte ratio.
Instructions En: Using either the absolute count or the percentage/relative count from a CBC with differential will yield the same NLR result.
Before Use: Launched during COVID-19 crisis.

Medium Description En: Assesses dysfunctional anxiety associated with the COVID-19 crisis.
Before Use: Launched during COVID-19 crisis.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Centrally Mediated Abdominal Pain Syndrome (CAPS)
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of centrally mediated abdominal pain syndrome (CAPS).
Instructions En:
Use in patients with chronic abdominal pain that is poorly related to gut function for at least 6 months.

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses to explain their abdominal pain even though centrally mediated abdominal pain syndrome may be present:

  • Signs or symptoms of gastrointestinal bleeding.

  • Unexplained iron deficiency anemia.

  • Unintentional weight loss.

  • Palpable abdominal mass or lymphadenopathy on exam.

  • Family history of GI cancer.

  • Onset of symptoms age ≥50 years and have not had age-appropriate colon cancer screening.

  • Sudden or acute onset or new change in bowel habit.

  • Recurrent nausea and vomiting.
Short Title En: Rome IV for Centrally Mediated Abdominal Pain Syndrome

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Infant Regurgitation
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of infant regurgitation.
Instructions En:
Use in infants 3 weeks to 12 months with regurgitation for at least 3 weeks.

Patients with any of the following alarm features should be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses:

  • Excessive irritability.

  • Onset <3 weeks, > 6 months or persistence >12 months of age.

  • Retching and/or persistent forceful vomiting.

  • Bilious or nocturnal vomiting.

  • Hematemesis.

  • Aspiration.

  • Respiratory symptoms (wheezing, stridor, cough, hoarseness).

  • Apnea.

  • BRUE (Brief Resolved Unexplained Event).

  • Weight loss or failure to thrive.

  • Feeding or swallowing difficulties including food refusal.

  • Abnormal neurologic exam, posturin or seizures

  • Dystonic neck posturing (Sandifer syndrome).

  • Chronic diarrhea or constipation.

  • Rectal bleeding.

  • Macro or Microcephaly.

  • Bulging fontanelle.

  • Hepatosplenomegaly.

  • Abdominal tenderness or distension.

  • Documented or suspected genetic/metabolic syndrome.

  • Fever.

  • Lethargy.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Fecal Incontinence
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of fecal incontinence.
Instructions En:
Use in patients with recurrent fecal staining or uncontrolled passage of stool for the past 3 months.

Do NOT use in patients with:

  • Clear mucous secretion alone.

  • Remote, isolated episodes of fecal incontinence.

  • Developmental age <4 years old or before toilet training has occurred.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Infant Functional Constipation
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of infant functional constipation.
Instructions En:
Use in infants and toddlers (<4 years of age) with symptoms suggestive of constipation such as passing hard, painful stools and exhibiting withholding behaviors for at least 1 month.

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though functional constipation may be present:

  • Constipation starting extremely early in life (<1 month).

  • Passage of meconium >48. 

  • Family history of Hirschsprung disease. 

  • Ribbon stools. 

  • Blood in the stool in the absence of anal fissures. 

  • Failure to thrive or unintentional weight loss.

  • Fever. 

  • Bilious vomiting. 

  • Severe abdominal distension. 

  • Abnormal physical exam findings including:

    • Tuft of hair on spine or sacral dimple.

    • Gluteal cleft deviation.

    • Perianal fistula.

    • Abnormal position of anus.

    • Absent anal or cremasteric reflex. 

    • Anal scars.

    • Decreased lower extremity strength/tone/reflex.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Functional Pancreatic Sphincter of Oddi Disorder (SOD)
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of functional pancreatic sphincter of oddi disorder.
Instructions En:
Use in patients with recurrent episodes of pancreatitis with characteristic pain and appropriate lab elevations. Other common etiologies of pancreatitis must be excluded with a negative endoscopic ultrasound (EUS). 

Do NOT use in patients with:

  • Pancreatic type pain without objective evidence of pancreatitis.
  • Single episode of idiopathic pancreatitis.
  • Gallstones or sludge on imaging.
  • Culprit drugs associated with pancreatitis (including over the counter, supplements, narcotics).

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Narcotic Bowel Syndrome
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of narcotic bowel syndrome.
Instructions En:
Use in patients with onset or increase of chronic abdominal pain treated with narcotics in which the pain worsens or does not resolve.

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though narcotic bowel syndrome may be present:

  • Signs or symptoms of gastrointestinal bleeding.

  • Unexplained iron deficiency anemia.

  • Unintentional weight loss.

  • Palpable abdominal mass or lymphadenopathy on exam.

  • Family history of GI cancer.

  • Onset of symptoms age ≥50 years and have not had age-appropriate colon cancer screening.

  • Sudden or acute onset of new change in bowel habit.
Short Title En: Rome IV for Narcotic Bowel Syndrome

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Infant Dyschezia
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of infant dyschezia.
Instructions En:
Use in an otherwise healthy infant <9 months with symptoms of infant dyschezia such as crying, turning red and straining for several minutes before successfully or unsuccessfully having a bowel movement. 

Infants with any of the following alarm features must be evaluated further:

  • Constipation.

  • Failure to thrive.

  • Bloody stools.

  • Vomiting.

  • Excessive irritability or crying.

  • Symptoms after 9 months of age.

  • Abdominal distension.

  • Abnormal physical exam.

  • Fever or illness.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Infant Functional Diarrhea
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of infant functional diarrhea.
Instructions En:
Use in otherwise healthy infants, toddlers and pre-school children with symptoms suggestive of functional diarrhea including daily painless diarrhea for at least 4 weeks. 

Patients with any of the following alarm features should be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses:

  • Weight loss.

  • Failure to thrive.

  • Abnormal growth.

  • Abdominal pain or distension.

  • Bloody stools.

  • Respiratory symptoms.

  • Abnormal perianal exam.

  • Vomiting.

  • Fever.

  • Family history of celiac disease, pancreatitis, inflammatory bowel disease.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Infant Colic
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of infant colic.
Instructions En:
Use in infants < 5 months with symptoms of infant colic such as recurrent and prolonged, unsoothable episodes of crying, fussing, or irritability that occur without obvious cause.

Patients with any of the following alarm features must be evaluated clinically for other anatomic, metabolic, infectious, neurological, or behavioral conditions:

  • Extreme or high-pitched cry.

  • Symptoms after 4 months of age.

  • Failure to thrive.

  • Developmental delays.

  • Maternal drug use.

  • Fever or illness.

  • Parental anxiety or maternal depression.

  • Abnormal physical examination.

  • Bloody stools.

  • Vomiting.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Infant Cyclic Vomiting Syndrome
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of infant cyclic vomiting syndrome.
Short Title En: Rome IV for Infant Cyclic Vomiting Syndrome

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Infant Rumination Syndrome
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of infant rumination syndrome.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Biliary Pain
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of biliary pain.
Instructions En:
Use in patients with symptoms characteristic of typical biliary pain as defined by Rome IV criteria.

If gallbladder present:

  • Supportive criteria such as low ejection fraction on gallbladder scintigraphy and normal liver transaminases, conjugated bilirubin, and amylase/lipase can aid in diagnosis of functional gallbladder disorder.

If gallbladder absent:

Supportive criteria such as normal amylase/lipase, abnormal sphincter of Oddi (SOD) manometry, or abnormal hepatobiliary scintigraphy can aid in diagnosis of sphincter of Oddi disorder.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Functional Gallbladder Disorder
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of functional gallbladder disorder.
Instructions En:
Use in patients with symptoms characteristic of typical biliary pain as defined by Rome IV criteria with gallbladder present.

Supportive criteria such as low ejection fraction on gallbladder scintigraphy (<40%) and normal liver enzymes, conjugated bilirubin, and amylase/lipase can aid in diagnosis.

Do NOT use these criteria in patients with:

  • Atypical symptoms for biliary colic (mild, transient, constant, daily).

  • Visualized cholelithiasis or microlithiasis/sludge on ultrasound or endoscopic ultrasound (EUS).

  • Structural abnormalities, especially biliary dilation or liver enzymes not explained by other cause: should consider EUS or magnetic resonance cholangiopancreaticography (MRCP).

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Functional Biliary Sphincter of Oddi Disorder (SOD)
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of functional biliary sphincter of Oddi disorder.
Instructions En:
Use in patients post-cholecystectomy with symptoms characteristic of typical biliary pain as defined by Rome IV criteria with elevated liver enzymes or dilated common bile duct, but NOT both. Supportive criteria such as normal amylase/lipase, abnormal sphincter of Oddi (SOD) manometry, or abnormal hepatobiliary scintigraphy can aid in diagnosis if available.

Do NOT use these criteria in patients with:

  • Atypical symptoms for biliary colic (mild, transient, constant, or daily pain).

  • Daily opiate use (can dilate bile ducts).

  • Structural diagnosis that explains symptoms (stones, pancreatitis, pancreatic or liver lesion).

  • With neither dilated common bile duct nor elevated liver tests.

  • With both dilated common bile duct and elevated liver tests.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Functional Anorectal Pain
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of levator ani syndrome or unspecified functional anorectal pain.
Instructions En:
Use in patients with chronic, recurrent anorectal pain lasting >30 minutes that is often worse with sitting than standing or lying down, often described as a vague, dull ache, or pressure high in rectum.

Digital rectal exam:

  • Levator Ani Syndrome: tenderness on palpation of pelvic floor or vagina.

    • Pain during posterior traction of puborectalis.

    • Pain often asymmetric, more often on left side (but not universally).

    • Posterior massage may elicit characteristic discomfort.

  • Unspecified Functional Anorectal Pain:

    • NO pain during posterior traction of puborectalis.

Do NOT use in patients with:

  • Anorectal or pelvic floor structural pathology explaining symptoms.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Proctalgia Fugax
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of proctalgia fugax.
Instructions En:
• Use in patients with sudden, infrequent anorectal pain lasting <30 minutes (often seconds to minutes) and often described as cramping, gnawing, aching, or stabbing with severity ranging from uncomfortable to intolerable.

  • Can interrupt normal activities and even awaken patients from sleep.

  • Can be triggered by stress or anxiety.

 

Do NOT use these criteria in patients with:

  • Tenderness on posterior traction of rectum when not having symptoms.

  • Anorectal or pelvic floor structural pathology explaining symptoms.

  • Frequent pain related to defecation

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Child Cyclic Vomiting Syndrome
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of child cyclic vomiting syndrome.
Instructions En:
Use in patients with symptoms suggestive of cyclic vomiting such as intense, paroxysmal, stereotypical episodes of vomiting, separated by weeks or months of usual health.

Patients with any of the following alarm features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though cyclic vomiting may be present:

  • Severe abdominal pain.
  • Persistent right upper or right lower quadrant pain.
  • Pain radiating to the back.
  • Dysphagia or odynophagia.
  • Persistent or bilious vomiting.
  • Gastrointestinal blood loss.
  • Chronic, unexplained or nocturnal diarrhea.
  • Involuntary weight loss.
  • Deceleration of linear growth.
  • Delayed puberty.
  • Recurrent or unexplained fever.
  • Dysuria or hematuria.
  • Personality changes.
  • Severe headaches.
  • Ataxia.
  • Altered mental status.
  • Any neurologic abnormality.
Short Title En: Rome IV for Child Cyclic Vomiting Syndrome

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Child Functional Nausea and Vomiting
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of child functional nausea and vomiting.
Instructions En:
Use in a child or adolescent with chronic nausea unrelated to meals, or vomiting in the absence of an eating disorder, of at least 2 months duration.

Patients with any of the following alarm features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though functional nausea or functional vomiting may be present:

  • Severe nausea and vomiting.

  • Vomiting occurs during the night or upon awakening.

  • Headaches, visual disturbances, endocrine abnormalities or behavior changes along with the nausea or vomiting.

  • Hematemesis.

  • Bilious emesis.

  • Abdominal distension.

  • Severe abdominal pain.
Short Title En: Rome IV for Child Nausea and Vomiting

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Child Rumination Syndrome
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of child rumination syndrome.
Instructions En:
Use in children and adolescents with symptoms suggestive of rumination, such as persistent or recurrent regurgitation of recently ingested food into the mouth with subsequent spitting or rechewing and re-swallowing for at least 2 months.

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though rumination syndrome may be present:

  • Dysphagia.

  • Odynophagia.

  • Persistent vomiting.

  • Vomiting later than 4h after a meal.

  • Nocturnal vomiting.

  • Unintentional weight loss.

  • Signs of upper gastrointestinal bleeding.

  • Severe abdominal pain.
Short Title En: Rome IV for Child Rumination Syndrome

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Child Aerophagia
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of child aerophagia.
Instructions En: Use in a child or adolescent with symptoms suggestive of aerophagia, such as excessive air swallowing, abdominal distension which increases throughout the day, repetitive belching or increased flatus of at least 2 months duration.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Child Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of child irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
Instructions En:
Use in a child or adolescent with symptoms suggestive of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), such as chronic and recurrent abdominal pain related to defecation and/or changes in stool frequency or form for at least 2 months.   

Patients with any of the following alarm features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though IBS may be present:

  • Family history of inflammatory bowel disease, celiac disease, or peptic ulcer disease.

  • Persistent right upper or right lower quadrant pain.

  • Dysphagia.

  • Odynophagia.

  • Persistent vomiting.

  • Gastrointestinal blood loss.

  • Nocturnal diarrhea.

  • Arthritis.

  • Perirectal disease.

  • Involuntary weight loss.

  • Deceleration of linear growth.

  • Delayed puberty.

  • Unexplained fever.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Child Abdominal Migraine
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of child abdominal migraine.
Instructions En:
Use in patients with symptoms suggestive of abdominal migraine such as intense, paroxysmal, stereotypical episodes of abdominal pain severe enough to interfere with activities, separated by weeks or months of usual health.

Patients with any of the following alarm features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though abdominal migraines may be present:

  • Persistent right upper or right lower quadrant pain.

  • Pain radiating to the back.

  • Dysphagia.

  • Odynophagia.

  • Persistent or bilious vomiting.

  • Gastrointestinal blood loss.

  • Chronic and unexplained diarrhea.

  • Nocturnal pain or diarrhea.

  • Arthritis.

  • Perirectal disease.

  • Involuntary weight loss.

  • Deceleration of linear growth.

  • Delayed puberty.

  • Recurrent or unexplained fever.

  • Dysuria or Hematuria.

  • Family history of inflammatory bowel disease, celiac disease, or peptic ulcer disease.
Short Title En: Rome IV for Child Abdominal Migraine

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Child Functional Abdominal Pain
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of child functional abdominal pain.
Instructions En:
Use in a child or adolescent with symptoms suggestive of functional abdominal pain such as episodic recurrent or chronic abdominal pain for at least 2 months.  

Patients with any of the following alarm features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though functional abdominal pain may be present:

  • Family history of inflammatory bowel disease, celiac disease, or peptic ulcer disease.

  • Persistent right upper or right lower quadrant pain.

  • Dysphagia.

  • Odynophagia.

  • Persistent vomiting.

  • Gastrointestinal blood loss.

  • Nocturnal diarrhea.

  • Arthritis.

  • Perirectal disease.

  • Involuntary weight loss.

  • Deceleration of linear growth.

  • Delayed puberty.

  • Unexplained fever.
Short Title En: Rome IV for Child Abdominal Pain

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Child Functional Constipation
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of child functional constipation.
Instructions En:
Use in children (> 4 years) and adolescents with symptoms suggestive of constipation such as passing hard, painful stools, fecal incontinence and/or showing withholding behaviors for at least 1 month.

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though functional constipation may be present:

  • Constipation onset extremely early in life (<1 mo).

  • Passage of meconium >48 hours after delivery.

  • Family history of Hirschsprung disease. 

  • Ribbon stools. 

  • Blood in the stools in the absence of anal fissures. 

  • Failure to thrive or unintentional weight loss.

  • Fever. 

  • Bilious vomiting. 

  • Severe abdominal distension. 

  • Fecal incontinence in the absence of rectal impaction.

  • Abnormal physical exam findings. 

  • Simultaneous urinary retention or incontinence.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Child Non-retentive Fecal Incontinence
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of child nonretentive fecal incontinence.
Instructions En:
Use in a child or adolescent with fecal incontinence for at least 1 month.  

Patients with any of the following alarm features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though nonretentive fecal incontinence may be present:

  • Physical exam findings suggesting structural disease, such as:

    • Fistulous opening.

    • Abnormalities of the back (Hair tuft, gluteal cleft deviation, sacral dimple).

    • Anal tenderness or tags.

    • Absent anal or cremasteric reflex.

    • Decreased lower extremity strength/tone/reflexes.

  • Anal scars.

  • Hematochezia or melena.

  • Abdominal distension.

  • Vomiting.

  • Urinary retention or incontinence.
Short Title En: Rome IV for Child Fecal Incontinence

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Child Functional Dyspepsia
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of child functional dyspepsia.
Instructions En:
Use in a child or adolescent with symptoms suggestive of functional dyspepsia for at least 2 months. The diagnosis of functional dyspepsia should be made by clinical history, positive symptom criteria, physical examination, minimal diagnostic testing as clinically indicated.  

Patients with any of the following alarm features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though functional dyspepsia may be present:

  • Persistent right upper or right lower quadrant pain.

  • Dysphagia.

  • Odynophagia.

  • Persistent vomiting.

  • Gastrointestinal blood loss.

  • Nocturnal pain or diarrhea.

  • Arthritis.

  • Perirectal disease.

  • Involuntary weight loss.

  • Deceleration of linear growth.

  • Delayed puberty.

  • Unexplained fever.

  • Family history of inflammatory bowel disease, celiac disease, or peptic ulcer disease.

Full Title En: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Functional Defecation Disorders
Medium Description En: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of functional defecation disorders.
Instructions En:
Patients who have symptoms consistent with functional constipation or IBS with constipation and in whom a defecation disorder is suspected. 

Do NOT use in patients:

  • Without age appropriate colorectal cancer screening.

  • With secondary intervenable causes for constipation (e.g. medications).
